resources.title: The importance of musicKanen Breen, Katie Noonan and Casey Donovan discuss the importance of music for student learning in schools.Duration: 2 minutes 15 seconds2m 15s

resources.title: Behind Yarrabil Bula: More First Nations SongsMeet the performers behind Yarrabil Bula: First Nations Songs. Learn about the value of using song to help revitalise language for all generations.Duration: 12 minutes 3 seconds12m

resources.title: Yarrabil Bula: The Greeting SongHello friends! How are you? Sing along and learn how to greet your friends in First Nations languages, including Yugambeh, Yawuru, Wiradjuri, Pitjantjatjara, palawa kani, Miriam Mer and Arrernte.Duration: 4 minutes 31 seconds4m 31s
resources.description: Hello friends! How are you? Sing along and learn how to greet your friends in First Nations languages, including Yugambeh, Yawuru, Wiradjuri, Pitjantjatjara, palawa kani, Miriam Mer and Arrernte.
topics: topic_aboriginal and torres strait islander history and culture

resources.title: Yarrabil Bula: Jubi in the JangeegeriJubi in the Jangeegeri (“A mud crab in the mangroves”) is a song written by Faith Baisden and performed by Alinta McGrady. This song incorporates animal names in the Yugambeh language.Duration: 3 minutes 21 seconds3m 21s
resources.description: Jubi in the Jangeegeri (“A mud crab in the mangroves”) is a song written by Faith Baisden and performed by Alinta McGrady. This song incorporates animal names in the Yugambeh language.
topics: topic_aboriginal and torres strait islander history and culture

resources.title: Wiradjuri Shake-a-Leg Hokey PokeyWiradjuri Shake-a-Leg Hokey Pokey is a song written and performed by Sharron mirii Bell. The song incorporates words in the Wiradjuri language.Duration: 3 minutes 38 seconds3m 38s
resources.description: Wiradjuri Shake-a-Leg Hokey Pokey is a song written and performed by Sharron mirii Bell. The song incorporates words in the Wiradjuri language.
topics: topic_aboriginal and torres strait islander history and culture

resources.title: Liyan NurluLiyan Nurlu ("Feelings song") is a song written by the Cable Beach Primary School's Yawuru Language Team, and performed by Bart Pigram and Maarli Pigram. The song is sung entirely in the Yawuru language.Duration: 2 minutes 32 seconds2m 32s
resources.description: Liyan Nurlu ("Feelings song") is a song written by the Cable Beach Primary School's Yawuru Language Team, and performed by Bart Pigram and Maarli Pigram. The song is sung entirely in the Yawuru language.
topics: topic_aboriginal and torres strait islander history and culture

resources.title: Counting Song in palawa kani Counting Song in palawa kani is a song written by Faith Baisden, translated by Theresa Sainty and performed by Merinda Sainty. This song is performed entirely in palawa kani language.Duration: 2 minutes 3 seconds2m 3s
resources.description: Counting Song in palawa kani is a song written by Faith Baisden, translated by Theresa Sainty and performed by Merinda Sainty. This song is performed entirely in palawa kani language.
topics: topic_aboriginal and torres strait islander history and culture

resources.title: Maṟa Kuḻunypa KutjuMara Kulunypa Kutju ("Five little fingers") is a song performed by Dominic Ngalatji Barry and Tjutjuna Paul Andy. The song is sung entirely in the Pitjantjatjara language.Duration: 3 minutes 8 seconds3m 8s
resources.description: Mara Kulunypa Kutju ("Five little fingers") is a song performed by Dominic Ngalatji Barry and Tjutjuna Paul Andy. The song is sung entirely in the Pitjantjatjara language.
topics: topic_aboriginal and torres strait islander history and culture

resources.title: Iwenhe Ingwele ArratemeIwenhe Ingwele Arrateme ("What comes out at night") is a song written by Children's Ground and performed by Myles Turner. This song is performed entirely in Arrernte language.Duration: 2 minutes 44 seconds2m 44s
resources.description: Iwenhe Ingwele Arrateme ("What comes out at night") is a song written by Children's Ground and performed by Myles Turner. This song is performed entirely in Arrernte language.

resources.title: Teaching media literacy in the Australian CurriculumHow can teachers approach teaching media literacy in the Australian Curriculum?  Professor Michael Dezuanni explores how teachers can find curriculum links across Media Arts and English, and a framework for critical thinking about all forms of media.Duration: 4 minutes 4 seconds4m 4s
resources.description: How can teachers approach teaching media literacy in the Australian Curriculum?  Professor Michael Dezuanni explores how teachers can find curriculum links across Media Arts and English, and a framework for critical thinking about all forms of media.

resources.title: Media Literacy classroom interventions that workWhat media literacy approaches or interventions have been shown to work in primary and secondary schools? Professor Michael Dezuanni explores the benefits of allowing students to be the experts through their experiences of digital media.Duration: 2 minutes 40 seconds2m 40s
resources.description: What media literacy approaches or interventions have been shown to work in primary and secondary schools? Professor Michael Dezuanni explores the benefits of allowing students to be the experts through their experiences of digital media.

resources.title: Developing literacy skills through media-makingHow does media-making form part of developing media literacy and digital literacy skills? Professor Michael Dezuanni suggests that teachers can use practical activities to help students think critically about the media landscape.Duration: 3 minutes 11 seconds3m 11s
resources.description: How does media-making form part of developing media literacy and digital literacy skills? Professor Michael Dezuanni suggests that teachers can use practical activities to help students think critically about the media landscape.

resources.title: Writing memoir can help young people with their self-expression and self-worthStudents need an opportunity to make sense of their own lives and memories. So for young people, memoir writing can be a lifeline. Author and teacher Amra Pajalic explains.

resources.title: In an increasingly digital world, it’s more important than ever for students to develop their handwriting skillsResearch studies have found there are many benefits to handwriting. But as students increasingly use more and more technology, their handwriting is being affected.
